formation.title: BTS SIO — SISR
formation.whatIs: BTS SIO (IT Services for Organizations) is a training focused on business IT. The SISR option (Infrastructure Solutions, Systems and Networks) specializes in networks, systems and cybersecurity.

formation.whySisrText: I identify with the infrastructure profile: understand, configure, secure and maintain reliable systems. My goal: build expertise in real professional environments.

about.title: About Me
about.p1: I'm Baptiste Dauvergne, a BTS SIO student specializing in SISR (Infrastructure Solutions, Systems and Networks) in Nîmes, France. Passionate about IT and technology, I'm developing my skills in system administration, network infrastructure management and user support.
about.p2: My goal is to keep growing in the fields of managed services and cybersecurity, combining technical rigor with a strong service mindset.

skills.title: Skills

gestion.title: Track assets, avoid surprises
gestion.subtitle: IT Asset Management
gestion.intro: IT asset management is the foundation for maintaining a clean IS: knowing what hardware exists, where it is, its condition and who uses it. It also enables anticipating failures, renewals and security.
gestion.mission: Client IT inventory update: on-site hardware verification, information consolidation and tracking update to facilitate maintenance and support.
gestion.context: The client had an incomplete inventory: some workstations weren't registered, equipment had changed users, and several details (model, serial number, location) were outdated.
gestion.objective: Obtain a reliable and usable inventory: workstations, peripherals, network equipment, with sufficient traceability to accelerate support and plan renewals.
gestion.role: On-site surveys, data consolidation and inventory update. I also standardized certain fields (names, locations, managers) for long-term readability.
actions: Verify on-site: workstations, screens, printers, visible switches/routers
Update key info: model, serial, condition, location, user
Implement naming logic (e.g.: PC-XXX / ROOM-XXX) for quick retrieval
Identify 'ghost' equipment (in the tool but absent on-site and vice versa)
Centralize useful info for support (OS, fixed IP, warranties, machine role)
gestion.proofText: What makes the difference isn't just 'doing an inventory': it's the ability to structure and make data reliable so it's useful daily (support + maintenance + security).
gestion.impactText1: I work with a 'field → tool → verification' logic: I collect, structure, then verify that information is coherent and reusable.
gestion.impactText2: A clean inventory reduces incidents, speeds up troubleshooting (knowing what equipment, where, for whom), and helps track updates/changes.

communication.title: Communicate to convince and convert
communication.subtitle: External Communication
communication.intro: How Cekoya communicates externally (image, acquisition, credibility) and how I apply the same logic to my personal projects (content & services).
communication.mission: Cekoya relies on several complementary levers: showcase website, LinkedIn, Google (presence + reviews), partnerships and trade shows. The goal: be visible, inspire trust, generate opportunities.
communication.context: Showcase website (clarity & credibility), LinkedIn (professional image & network), Google (be found & recommended), Partnerships (field credibility), Trade shows (visibility & trust).
communication.objective: External communication works when coherent: same message everywhere (website, LinkedIn, Google), and a reputation that confirms that message.
communication.role: Analysis of communication levers, applying the same logic to personal projects: show, reassure, convert. Content serves as proof.
actions: Content: attract through proof — show quality level (rhythm, transitions, sound design)
Trust: clarity & responsiveness — clear expectations, announced timelines, precise feedback
Offer: readability & process — what's included, how it works, what's delivered
Showcase website: reassure quickly (first impression)
LinkedIn: build credibility + create contacts
communication.proofText: I know how to 'sell through proof': my content reassures, my speech is clear, and my offer is simple. Same foundation as effective external communication in business.
communication.impactText1: Same message everywhere (website, LinkedIn, Google). Reputation confirms the message (partners, feedback, presence).
communication.impactText2: I follow the same logic: show, reassure, convert. My content serves as direct proof of quality.

support.title: Diagnose fast, fix properly
support.subtitle: Support & Network Incidents
support.intro: During my internship at Cekoya (Nîmes), I participated in client IT support: network incidents, unavailable services, unstable workstations, printing, resource access. Support is mainly a method: identify, isolate, fix, then validate.
support.mission: Network incident: shares and printers unavailable on multiple workstations after equipment modification (router/switch). Goal: quickly restore service access without further impacting production.
support.context: Multiple users report: inability to access shared folders, printers unfindable and unstable connections. The problem seems to affect a specific network zone.
support.objective: Restore service access (shares, printers, apps) and verify stability. Once correction applied, validate with affected users.
support.role: DHCP/DNS lead, VLAN error, defective cable/port, or addressing conflict. The idea is to isolate whether it's a workstation or network problem.
actions: Quickly check if the issue affects one or multiple workstations
Check addressing: IP, gateway, DNS, DHCP lease and network coherence
Test resource access: ping gateway, server, shares, printers
Isolate the zone: switch port / VLAN / network equipment linked to affected workstations
Apply correction then validate with a real case (shares + printing)
support.proofText: IT support requires both technique and rigor. My key point: I follow a clear method to reduce downtime while keeping a clean result (tests, validation, explanation if needed).
support.impactText1: I address what blocks most first (access to essential resources), then verify stability before closing. Goal: return to production ASAP.
support.impactText2: A correction is never 'assumed': it's tested. I validate on a real workstation, then confirm with users that everything is back to normal.

projet.title: 4G backup solution deployment
projet.subtitle: Technical Project
projet.intro: Mission completed during my internship at Cekoya (Nîmes), in a managed services context with professional clients (SMBs, stores, administrative structures).
projet.mission: In this project, I was responsible for the technical part related to the 4G router: preparation, configuration, failover and tests. The goal: deliver a reliable configuration ready for on-site integration.
projet.context: A client experienced regular main Internet connection outages, directly impacting: access to business tools, IP telephony and employee productivity.
projet.objective: Ensure an automatically-activated backup connection, without manual intervention, to reduce the impact of outages on client activity.
projet.role: Responsible for the technical part: preparation, configuration, failover and tests. Team project with a reference technician for on-site integration.
actions: 4G preparation: connection setup (SIM card / operator parameters), admin access security
Failover configuration: automatic switching between main line and 4G
Outage detection and automatic return when main connection becomes stable
Simulated outage tests: verify 4G switch-over, connection stability
Confirm automatic return to main line
projet.proofText: The solution is validated when the client maintains a functional connection despite an Internet outage, and the failover (and return) happens automatically and stably.
projet.impactText1: Stable solution, simple to maintain, reliable failover. Validation through realistic tests before production.
projet.impactText2: On-site integration and global validation done with the reference technician. Technical preparation done autonomously.

assistance.title: Support and empower users
assistance.subtitle: User Assistance
assistance.intro: During my internship at Cekoya (Nîmes), I was often in contact with users (remotely or on-site). The goal: quickly resolve an incident while clearly explaining what's happening and what I'm doing.
assistance.mission: New workstation deployment and setup after incident, with user environment recovery and network verifications.
assistance.context: A user couldn't work properly: slowdowns, crashes, and random access to resources (network drives/printing/applications). Priority: get them operational quickly.
assistance.objective: Provide a stable workstation, recover work environment (accounts, access, tools), and guide the user to be autonomous on simple checks.
assistance.role: Workstation installation and configuration, domain/network reintegration if needed, verifications (DHCP/DNS, shares, printers), then user accompaniment.
actions: Prepare a 'clean' workstation: updates, drivers, basic setup
Verify connectivity: shares, printing, applications, browsing access
Explain to user: what was done + how to prevent recurrence
Validate: user tests their real tasks before closing
assistance.proofText: User assistance isn't just about 'fixing'. The key point I developed: the ability to translate a technical problem into simple actions for the user.
assistance.impactText1: I explain what I do in simple terms, reassure the user, and give 2-3 quick checks they can redo alone (Wi-Fi, cable, restart, etc.).
assistance.impactText2: I validate on 'real' usage: the user tests their usual tasks (printing, apps, folders). Ticket closed only when workstation is truly functional.

infra.title: Network Infrastructure

watch.title: Tech Watch

before.title: Before virtualization
before.text: Classic model: 1 physical server = 1 service. Limitations: resource underutilization (10-20%), high costs, poor flexibility, critical failures.

vmware.title: VMware's arrival
vmware.text: Late 1990s: hypervisor democratization. Separation of hardware from OS. One physical machine can host multiple isolated logical servers.

today.title: VMware Today
today.text: Major player with ESXi, vSphere, vCenter, VMware Cloud.
features: vSAN: distributed storage without physical SAN
HA: automatic VM restart on failure

watch.sources: Sources: Google Alerts, LeMondeInformatique, ZDNet, Tom's Hardware, VMware Community, Reddit r/sysadmin
